court: High Court of Judicature at Bombay

facts.text: Afco Private Ltd. is a private limited company.

anchor.surface_text: Afco Private Ltd., a private limited companypany,

facts.text: Year of account ending March 31, 1955 for Afco Private Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: For the year of account ending March 31, 1955, Afco Private Ltd., a private limited companypany,

facts.text: Afco Private Ltd. earned total income computed by Income-tax Appellate Tribunal at Rs. 49,843.

anchor.surface_text: earned a total income which was finally companyputed in assessment proceedings by order of the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, at Rs. 49,843.

facts.text: Afco Private Ltd. declared dividend of Rs. 11,712 on July 13, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany declared a dividend of Rs. 11,712 on July 13, 1955,

facts.text: Afco Private Ltd. declared additional dividend of Rs. 5,612 before close of assessment year 1955-56.

anchor.surface_text: and before the close of the year of assessment 1955-56 declared an additional dividend of Rs. 5,612,

facts.text: Aggregate dividends distributed by Afco Private Ltd. not less than 60% of total income reduced by income-tax and super-tax.

anchor.surface_text: thereby distributing in the aggregate dividend which was number less than 60 of the total income, reduced by the income-tax and super-tax payable by it.

facts.text: Afco Private Ltd. claimed rebate at one anna in the rupee per Finance Act 15 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany then claimed rebate at the rate of one anna in the rupee on the amount companyputed according to Schedule I, Part I, item B, read with section 2 of the Finance Act  15 of 1955 .

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected the rebate claim because section 23A applicable to the company.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected the claim because in their view the claimant was a companypany to which the provisions of section 23A of the Income-tax Act companyld number be made applicable.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected the rebate claim.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected the claim because in their view the claimant was a companypany to which the provisions of section 23A of the Income-tax Act companyld number be made applicable.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal reversed the order of income-tax authorities.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Bombay, reserved the order of the income-tax authorities.

facts.text: Tribunal opined that rebate benefit available if conditions in section 23A fulfilled.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal opined that the expression cannot be made applicable in item B of Part I of Schedule I of the Finance Act  15 of 1955  must be read in companyjunction with section 23A of the Income-tax Act, and the benefit of rebate provided by the Finance Act, 1955, cannot be denied to a private companypany if the companyditions prescribed in section 23A 1  are fulfilled.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal referred question to High Court of Judicature at Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The following question referred by the Tribunal to the High Court of Judicature at Bombay was answered in the affirmative

facts.text: High Court answered the referred question in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the assessee companypany having distributed dividends of over 60 of the companypanys total income less income-tax and super-tax payable thereon is entitled to the rebate of 1 anna per rupee on the undistributed balance of profits as provided in clause  i  of the proviso to item B of Part I of the First Schedule to the Finance Act of 1955 ?

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that assessee company entitled to rebate claimed.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal and the High Court were right in so holding.

facts.text: Section 23A(1) of Income-tax Act authorised ITO to order super-tax on undistributed balance if dividends less than 60%.

anchor.surface_text: By section 23A 1  of the Income-tax Act at the material time the Income-tax officer was authorised to order a companypany to pay super-tax, at the rate of eight annas in the rupee in the case of a companypany whose business companysisted wholly or mainly in the dealings in or holding of investment, and at the rate of four annas in the case of any other companypany, on the undistributed balance of the total income of the previous year,

facts.text: Section 23A(9) does not apply to companies in which public substantially interested.

anchor.surface_text: By the first paragraph of sub-section  9  of section 23A it is provided that Nothing companytained in this section shall apply to any companypany in which the public are substantially interested or to a subsidiary companypany of such companypany

facts.text: Private company as defined in Indian Companies Act, 1913 is not a company in which public substantially interested per Explanation 1(b) to section 23A.

anchor.surface_text: Explanation 1, in so far as it is material to this case, provides Explanation 1. - For the purpose of this section, a companypany shall be deemed to be a companypany in which the public are substantially interested -  b  if it is number a private companypany as defined in the Indian Companies Act, 1913  VII of 1913 ,

facts.text: Finance Act 15 of 1955 amended section 23A(1).

anchor.surface_text: By the Finance Act  15 of 1955  section 23A 1  was amended and the Income-tax Officer was directed to make an order that the companypany shall be liable to pay super-tax on the undistributed balance at the rates prescribed under the section.

facts.text: Income-tax authorities held that private companies not entitled to rebate as section 23A can be made applicable.

facts.text: Tribunal and High Court held that rebate available if no order under section 23A justified.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal and the High Court held that the expression cannot be made applicable only refers to a state of affairs in which having regard to the circumstances an order under section 23A of the Indian Income-tax Act cannot be made.

facts.text: Legislative history of Finance Acts prior to 1955 provided rebate if no order under section 23A made.

anchor.surface_text: In the Finance Acts prior to 1955 rebate under Part I of the First Schedule, item B, was admissible if the companypany had in respect of profits liable to tax under the Indian Income-tax Act made the prescribed arrangements for declaration and payment of dividends payable out of the profits and had deducted super-tax from the dividends in accordance with section 18 3D  and  3E , where the total income reduced by seven annas in the rupee and the amount exempt from income-tax exceed the amount of any dividends declared and numberorder had been made under sub-section  1  of section 23A of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Finance Act 1955 modified rebate scheme to simplify procedure.

issues.text: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the assessee company having distributed dividends of over 60 of the companys total income less income-tax and super-tax payable thereon is entitled to the rebate of 1 anna per rupee on the undistributed balance of profits as provided in clause i of the proviso to item B of Part I of the First Schedule to the Finance Act of 1955?

anchor.surface_text: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the assessee company having distributed dividends of over 60 of the companys total income less income-tax and super-tax payable thereon is entitled to the rebate of 1 anna per rupee on the undistributed balance of profits as provided in clause i of the proviso to item B of Part I of the First Schedule to the Finance Act of 1955?

issues.text: Whether the expression 'a company to which the provisions of section 23A of the Income-tax Act cannot be made applicable' refers to companies permanently excluded from section 23A irrespective of circumstances or only to cases where an order under section 23A cannot justifiably be made due to adequate dividend distribution?

anchor.surface_text: The income-tax authorities held that the expression company to which the provisions of section 23A of the Income-tax Act cannot be made applicable is descriptive of a class of companies against which in no circumstances can an order under section 23A of the Indian Income-tax be made, and private limited companies being companies in respect of which an order under section 23A of the Income-tax Act can be made if the conditions prescribed relating to distribution of dividend are fulfilled, the benefit of rebate is not admissible in their favour.

arguments.claim: The expression 'a company to which the provisions of section 23A of the Income-tax Act cannot be made applicable' is descriptive of a class of companies against which in no circumstances can an order under section 23A be made, and private limited companies are not entitled to rebate since an order can be made if dividend conditions not fulfilled

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior acts tied rebate to actual absence of s23A order; 1955 simplifies without changing substantive eligibility for private companies.

holdings.text: It appears that the legislature modified the scheme of granting rebate in enacting the Finance Act of 1955, with a view to simplify the procedure and avoid delays, and number with the object of depriving the private limited companypanies as a class, of the benefit of rebate which was permissible under the earlier Acts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1955 changes administrative, not substantive; no intent to bar private companies from rebate met via dividend distribution.
